profileText: A Senator from Florida; born Paula Fickes in Salt Lake City, Salt Lake County, Utah, January 24, 1927; attended the public schools of Salt Lake City and Richmond, Utah, and Atlanta, Ga.; attended Utah State University 1944-1947; member, Florida Public Service Commission 1972-1979; vice president, Air Florida 1979-1980; director, Rural Telephone Bank Board 1972-1978; member, President's Commission on White House Fellowships 1975; served on Federal Energy Administration Consumer Affairs/Special Impact Advisory Committee 1974-1976; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in 1980 for the six-year term commencing January 3, 1981; subsequently appointed January 1, 1981, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Richard B. Stone for the term ending January 3, 1981, and served from January 1, 1981, to January 3, 1987; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1986; was a resident of Winter Park, Fla., until her death on December 4, 2009; interment in Palm Cemetery, Winter Park, Fla.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Hawkins, Paula. Children at Risk, My Fight Against Child Abuse: A Personal Story and a Public Plea. Bethesda, MD: Adler & Adler, 1986.

"Paula Fickes Hawkins," in Women in Congress, 1917-2006. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 2006.

researchRecord.name: 1972-1986. 59 commercials. Used during Hawkins' campaigns for the 1972 Public Service Commissioner election and the 1980 and 1986 senatorial elections in Florida.

May 7, 1974 and November 11, 1997. Part of the Florida Politics collection of interviews held by the Samuel Proctor Oral History Program of the Department of History. Available on University of Florida Digital Collections.

1980-1987. 294 cubic feet. Senatorial papers including correspondence with political figures, legislative activity records, letters, photographs, ephemera, awards, and campaign materials. Subjects include cross-Florida barge canal, immigration, citrus industry, agriculture, foreign trade, and illegal drugs. Finding aid available.
